title: Relates to county plans for improving the availability of community services to the elderly
summary: Relates to procedures for amendments to county plans for improving the availability of community services to the elderly; requires approval of director for amendments; requires opportunity for input from stakeholders, service providers and the elderly.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S1997

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the elder law, in relation to county plans for improving the
availability of community services to the elderly

PURPOSE:
Require the State Office for Aging to solicit input from providers,
consumers, and stakeholders when approving or disapproving county
aging plans or plan amendments. Such input is specifically made one
of the factors to be considered in approving or disapproving the plans.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
Section 1. Amends subdivision 2 of section 214 of the elder law to
make it clear that any change in a county aging plan submitted to the
state office for the aging (SOFA) after approval shall require the
filing of a proposed plan amendment, which would include any change
in service delivery, to the director for approval or disapproval, and
that no plan amendment is effective until approved by the director.
Requires that SOFA approve the amendment within 60 days after receipt
of completed documentation required. Makes a series of technical
changes to the requirements to make clear that certain of the factors
apply to amendments and certain to plans, and certain to both-for
example, to require an identification of planning, coordination, and
administrative activities necessary to achieve the goals and
objectives of the plan or plan amendment, together with a budget
request for such activities. This portion also includes a requirement
that the following be included with respect to any new initiative or
any initiative changed from a preceding year or any plan amendment:

* a description and analysis at a level of detail prescribed by the
director showing the number of seniors who would be affected by each
new or changed initiative;
* the demographics and annual and long term projections of the numbers
of seniors proposed to be served by each initiative;
* the financial sustainability of such initiatives;
* whether there will be any diminishment of services as result of this
new or changed initiative, how such change would be measured, and
efforts that will be made to counteract any negative impact; and
* comparisons of the cost of current and changed initiatives, where
appropriate, to be borne by the designated agency and providers of
services.

Further, requires that the director of SOFA take any comments and
reports from stakeholders, providers, and seniors into account, in
addition to other requirements, as the basis for approval of a county
plan, or amendment.

Finally, requires that designated agencies (i.e., area agencies on
aging) comply with the provisions of approved plans, and with the

results of State hearings or reviews, unless and until an amended
plan or application is approved by the office, and allows SOFA to
issue binding program instructions on area agencies and service
providers with respect to such plans or amended plans.

Section 2. Provides a severability clause.

Section 3. Provides for an immediate effective date.

EXISTING LAW:
Section 214 of the Elder law relates to county plans for improving the
availability of community services to the elderly.

JUSTIFICATION:
Counties are required to submit an annual aging plan or plan update in
order to continue qualification as an area agency on aging, and to
spend State and federal funds on behalf of programs and services for
seniors. The plans must include several key components, and must show
how the county is improving the delivery of community services for
elderly persons.
Strangely, while the local area agencies on aging are required to
conduct a public hearing on the plan submission, the State Office for
Aging is not required to take consumer and provider information or
testimony into account in approving a plan, update, or plan
amendment. This legislation closes that gap. It not only requires
SOFA to consider such input, it specifically makes the consideration
party of the final approval process. Moreover, it requires some
specific information be submitted to SOFA by the county with respect
to new initiatives, whether these are submitted as part of the plan
or as a plan amendment. The several pieces in this act concerning the
required submission of plan amendments are not new; rather they are
statutory clarifications of existing requirements. This measure, if
approved, will provide for a more robust approval process of local
plans by the State Office for Aging.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
S.2005 - 2009-10 Referred to Aging
S.8457 - 2007-08 Referred to Rules, Passed Senate

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

LOCAL FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:

None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
Immediately.
